awd_titl_txt: Promoting Engineering Problem Framing Skill-Development in High School Science and Engineering Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. This collaborative project involving Ohio Northern University, Ohio State University, and Olathe Northwest High School will develop curricular activities and assessment guidance for K-12 science and engineering educators who seek to incorporate engineering design content into their biology, chemistry, and physics classes. This work is important because students' limited exposure to engineering activities can negatively impact their decisions to enroll in STEM courses and to pursue engineering careers. Further, many states are adopting or considering adopting the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), a set of classroom standards which integrate engineering content into traditional science disciplines. While high school teachers under these standards are expected to incorporate the cross-cutting engineering content into their courses, they generally receive little high-quality support for doing so. If successful, the project could provide a powerful model of how to support busy and resource-constrained STEM teachers, and create broader student interest in STEM careers.
 
Drawing from best practices on instructional design, the project's main objectives are to: (1) design, field-test, and evaluate the impact of 12 NGSS-aligned, engineering problem-framing design activities on students enrolled in grades 9-12 science courses and (2) design and conduct high-quality, sustained professional development that fosters participating high school science teachers' ability to deploy the NGSS concepts-linked activities. Data sources include student design artifacts, video of classroom instruction, and surveys assessing student and teacher attitudes toward engineering, student design self-efficacy and teacher self-efficacy for teaching engineering content. These data will be analyzed to determine what teachers learned from the professional development activities, how those activities informed their teaching and in turn, how students' engagement with the engineering activities relates to their engineering design skills and attitudes. In terms of intellectual merit, the project aims to develop a learning progression of students' engineering design problem-framing skills by characterizing any observed change in students' design work and attitudes over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Building Informed Designers project provides accessible resources for high school STEM teachers to incorporate engineering into their classrooms. The project development team, comprised of educators with high school and college engineering experience, created and disseminated readily deployable activities aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards. Teacher resources include lesson plans, slide decks, interactive modules, context suggestions, worksheets, design canvases, and other support tools for both in-person and remote learning. Activities focus on engineering “problem framing” - initial design process steps intended to gather a comprehensive understanding of a problem before considering detailed solutions. In other words, before jumping into the design-build-test phase, students are encouraged to think holistically about potential problems. 

Activities are modular so that teachers are able to select any single activity or facilitate the entire series. For example, depending on students’ understanding of the engineering field, teachers may opt to include an activity that helps define engineering, identifying similarities and differences with science. Subsequent activities include content such as…

  • Stakeholders: helps build empathy to better understand others’ needs

  • Opportunity recognition: guides exploration of societal improvement possibilities 

  • Design specifications: quantifies design characteristics to evaluate, constrain, and inform design decisions 

  • Inquiry: supports question formulation to gain insight from stakeholders, experts, and relevant publications

  • Assumptions: fills knowledge gaps with reasonable estimations to advance the project

  • Market alternatives: highlights unique differentiation opportunities apart from currently available solutions

  • Broader impacts: focuses on potential benefits and drawbacks with respect to the environment, human well-being, and the economy

These activity components were crafted to foster “thinking like an engineer.”  Activities are grounded in authentic contexts to highlight direct out-of-classroom engineering connections. The variety of contextualization allows teachers to repeat activities to re-emphasize key content. 

Over the course of the project, several teacher trainings were provided to teachers directly related to the project activities (17 unique teachers over the four years) through which nearly  1600 students were impacted. The project team also provided an engineering-design-integration professional development session for all high school science teachers in the participating school district (over 100 teachers participated).  Every training session for project participants involved some experience with an engineering design activity and reflection on how science and engineering integrated within that experience. As a result of the district science teachers professional development session, several teachers, who were not directly participating in the research portion of the project, requested resources and guidance on integrating the demonstrated project into their work with their students. This demonstrated the project’s presence in the district impacted a larger number of teachers and students than shown in the base numbers.

Student work artifacts were studied to explore how they were thinking about engineering design within the context of the activities and used to refine the materials and teacher professional development. Additionally, an assessment instrument, the Engineering Design Value-Expectancy Scale (EDVES) was developed, deployed, and validated using both high school and collegiate first-year engineering students. This instrument measures student self-efficacy, value beliefs, and their motivational drivers related to engineering design. This tool can provide evidence of the effectiveness of an engineering design intervention used with high school and higher education students as part of a pre/post experimental or quasi-experimental design structure.
